transcripts.text: Are there any benefits to being a Christian who struggles as a psychopath?

Yeah, some of them, I don't know if I'd call them benefits, but there are things like, you know, we all have to experience everyone around us dying at some point, and you never experience the pain.  But there's another sense in which I would want to experience the pain, right?  I would rather experience the pain of someone dying, but it means you don't have to deal with a lot of grief like that.  You, you, you, you're not, you're not scared in most situations that most people would be scared in.  So you don't, you don't have to live in, in fear.  You, you, yeah, you don't get, you don't get anxiety when things are going wrong.  You're, You're generally the coolest headed person in any situation when things are going wrong.  And, you know, depending on what you're doing as a Christian, some of those things can actually be helpful.  Like I deal with Islam.  People say they're going to murder me and my family regularly and that they're going to torture me and rape my wife and all these things.  And it just doesn't scare me at all.  So it allows you to kind of keep moving forward and not being put down by, you know, things that...
Your wife probably doesn't like that though, right?

No, no, no.  Most people don't like that, but it allows you to say, look, here's what I'm going to do and nothing in this world is going to stop me and you can torture me and kill me and you're still not going to stop me.  So again... You would probably not want to have the psychopathy.  You'd probably not want to have it.  But if you've got it, you might as well make the best of it that you can.  And you can face a lot of situations that would cause a lot of other people to crumble.  And you just keep moving forward.
